title: Why you procrastinate even when it feels bad

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason people procrastinate, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: They are lazy and lack motivation

options.label: B
options.text: They are trying to avoid tasks that evoke negative feelings

options.label: C
options.text: They are not good at time management

options.label: D
options.text: They are perfectionists and want to do everything flawlessly

multiple-choice.question: Which part of the brain is involved in emotional processing and threat identification, leading to procrastination?

options.label: A
options.text: It releases hormones that promote relaxation and calmness

options.label: B
options.text: It releases hormones that kick off a fear response

options.label: C
options.text: It shuts down and becomes unresponsive

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes more rational and logical

multiple-choice.question: According to studies, what type of tasks are people more likely to procrastinate?

options.label: C
options.text: Tasks that require a lot of time and effort

options.label: D
options.text: Tasks that are repetitive and boring

multiple-choice.question: What is a common misconception about people who procrastinate?

options.label: A
options.text: They are lazy and lack motivation

options.label: B
options.text: They are not good at time management

options.label: C
options.text: They are perfectionists and want to do everything flawlessly

options.label: D
options.text: They are more likely to be extroverted and outgoing

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential consequence of frequent procrastination?

options.label: C
options.text: Reduced stress levels and improved mental health

options.label: D
options.text: Anxiety, depression, and physical ailments associated with high stress

multiple-choice.question: According to researchers, what is a more effective approach to breaking the cycle of procrastination?

options.label: A
options.text: Cultivating discipline and practicing strict time management

options.label: B
options.text: Being too hard on oneself and layering additional bad emotions onto a task

options.label: C
options.text: Addressing and reducing negative emotions associated with a task

options.label: D
options.text: Ignoring the task and hoping it goes away

multiple-choice.question: What is a simple strategy for reducing procrastination?

options.label: A
options.text: Breaking a task into smaller elements

options.label: C
options.text: Removing all distractions and working in complete silence

multiple-choice.question: What attitude can help individuals overcome procrastination?
What is the ultimate consequence of a culture that perpetuates the cycle of stress and procrastination?

options.label: C
options.text: Reduced stress levels and improved mental health

options.label: D
options.text: Hurt to all individuals in the long term

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: It reverses the movement of food

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because the brain receives more signals from the vagus nerve

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Foods with more protein, fiber, and water

options.label: C
options.text: Foods with more fat and salt

options.label: D
options.text: Foods with more calories and additives

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Through the release of insulin from the pancreas

options.label: C
options.text: Through the production of ghrelin by the empty stomach

options.label: D
options.text: Through the stretching of the stomach wall as it fills with food

options.label: A
options.text: The sensation of fullness becomes permanent

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: Why sitting is bad for you - Murat Dalkilinç

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the body when it stays seated for an extended period?

options.label: B
options.text: The body's muscles and joints are strengthened.

options.label: C
options.text: The body becomes agitated and counts down the moments until it can move again.

options.text: It puts even pressure on the spine.

options.label: C
options.text: It causes wear and tear on the spinal discs and overworks certain ligaments and joints.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the spine.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on the enzyme.

options.label: C
options.text: It temporarily deactivates the enzyme, reducing fat breakdown.

options.label: C

options.text: Taking a long walk after a prolonged sitting period

options.label: D
options.text: Doing nothing, as the effects are irreversible

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D

title: The best way to apologize (according to science)

multiple-choice.question: What is considered the "centerpiece of an apology" according to some researchers?

options.label: A
options.text: Offering a repair for the damage caused

options.label: B
options.text: Understanding and accepting responsibility for one's actions

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of a good apology?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the person apologizing feel better

options.label: B
options.text: To seek forgiveness and move on

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the perspective of the wronged party and repair the damage to the relationship

multiple-choice.question: What should be the focus of an apology when the mistake was not an accident?

options.label: B
options.text: Working to understand the other person's perspective

multiple-choice.question: How can asking the wronged party how they felt help in an apology?

options.label: A
options.text: It can help the person apologizing feel better

options.label: B
options.text: It can help rationalize the person's actions

options.label: C
options.text: It can provide clarity on how the person's actions caused harm

options.label: D
options.text: It can make the apology more defensive

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of clearly acknowledging wrongdoing in an apology?

options.label: A
options.text: To shift the blame to someone else

options.label: C
options.text: To indicate that one knows exactly how they messed up and will behave differently moving forward

options.label: D
options.text: To make excuses for one's behavior

multiple-choice.question: What is the "offer of repair" in an apology, according to researchers?

options.label: A
options.text: A verbal commitment to make the same mistake again

options.label: B
options.text: A gesture to repair the damage caused by one's offense

options.label: C
options.text: A statement to justify one's actions

options.label: D
options.text: A promise to forget the incident

multiple-choice.question: Why is promising to do better only effective if one actually does better?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it makes the person apologizing feel better

options.label: C
options.text: Because it shows that one is committed to change and growth

options.label: D
options.text: Because it shifts the blame to someone else

multiple-choice.question: What are some elements of a good apology, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Taking the victim's perspective, accepting responsibility, and making concrete offers of repair

options.label: B
options.text: Making excuses, justifying one's actions, and shifting the blame

options.label: C
options.text: Focusing on one's own feelings, rationalizing one's actions, and forgetting the incident

options.label: D
options.text: Seeking forgiveness, moving on, and ignoring the incident

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of an apology, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To get forgiveness and move on

options.label: B
options.text: To express remorse and accept accountability

options.label: C
options.text: To justify one's actions and shift the blame

options.label: D
options.text: To make the person apologizing feel better

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between a good apology and reconciliation, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A good apology is the final step on the road to reconciliation

options.label: B
options.text: A good apology is just the first step on the road to reconciliation

options.label: C
options.text: A good apology is not necessary for reconciliation

title: Does working hard really make you a good person? - Azim Shariff

options.text: Jeff was asked to work overtime and had to decide whether to accept.

options.text: They saw him as less competent but warmer and more moral.

options.text: They saw him as more competent and more moral.

options.label: B
options.text: They were seen as less competent and less moral.

options.label: C
options.text: They were seen as less competent but more moral.

options.label: D
options.text: They were seen as more competent and more moral.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It leads to increased job satisfaction.

options.label: D
options.text: It leads to increased job satisfaction.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's argument regarding hard work?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Hard work is never meaningful and should be avoided.

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Should you care what your parents think?

multiple-choice.question: What is reactance theory in psychology?

options.label: A
options.text: A motivational state that occurs when people feel their freedom is being threatened.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of behavioral disorder that causes people to act impulsively.

options.label: C
options.text: A theory that explains why people tend to follow rules and authority.

options.label: D
options.text: A concept that describes the importance of social networks in relationships.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what happens when people perceive health campaigns as overbearing?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more likely to follow the campaign's advice.

options.label: B
options.text: They ignore the campaign and do the opposite of what is recommended.

options.label: C
options.text: They become more aware of the health issue and take action to prevent it.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not care about the campaign and do nothing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Romeo and Juliet Effect in psychology?

options.label: A
options.text: A phenomenon where forbidden love becomes stronger due to parental disapproval.

options.label: B
options.text: A theory that explains why people tend to follow rules and authority.

options.label: C
options.text: A concept that describes the importance of social networks in relationships.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of behavioral disorder that causes people to act impulsively.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the outcome of most follow-up studies on the Romeo and Juliet Effect?

options.label: A
options.text: The studies confirmed the original findings and supported the Romeo and Juliet Effect.

options.label: B
options.text: The studies found that the Romeo and Juliet Effect only applies to certain cultures.

options.label: C
options.text: The studies suggested that the opposite of the Romeo and Juliet Effect is true.

options.label: D
options.text: The studies found no correlation between parental disapproval and relationship strength.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Social Network Effect in psychology?

options.label: A
options.text: A phenomenon where forbidden love becomes stronger due to parental disapproval.

options.label: B
options.text: A theory that explains why people tend to follow rules and authority.

options.label: C
options.text: A concept that describes the importance of social networks in relationships.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of behavioral disorder that causes people to act impulsively.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, why doesn't reactance win out over the Social Network Effect?

options.label: A
options.text: Because people value their existing relationships over their potential relationships.

options.label: B
options.text: Because disapproving friends and family are just voicing negative opinions or passively not supporting a relationship.

options.label: C
options.text: Because people with good relationships with their parents feel they can ignore their parent's advice without serious consequences.

options.label: D
options.text: Because people with bad parental relationships often don't care what they think anyway.

multiple-choice.question: What are the two types of reactance mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: They do the opposite of what they are told.

options.label: B
options.text: They ignore the request and do what they believe is appropriate.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the outcome for relationships that find supportive social networks?

options.label: A
options.text: They tend to fail due to external pressures.

options.label: B
options.text: They tend to succeed despite external pressures.

options.label: C
options.text: They remain unchanged despite external pressures.

options.label: D
options.text: They become more isolated and withdrawn.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what can help buffer against disapproval from others in romantic relationships?

options.label: A
options.text: Support from a few close companions.
